thread.title: Teenage golfer shows up Sir Bob Charles with an ace
thread.title_full: Teenage golfer shows up Sir Bob Charles with an ace

author: Jonathan Leask
title: Teenage golfer shows up Sir Bob Charles with an ace

organizations.name: david walker/fairfax nz  kaiapoi gold club

text:
Teenage golfer shows up Sir Bob Charles with an ace JONATHAN LEASK Last updated 18:30, February 7 2017 DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Kaiapoi Gold Club's Mitchell Berry, right, gets a high five from Sir Bob Charles for his hole in one off the first tee. 
The crowd had come to see New Zealand's greatest golfer but a 15-year-old local stole the show at the Kaiapoi Golf Club. 
Sir Bob Charles went to the North Canterbury club for a round of golf with some of the club's up and coming juniors on Sunday. 
Playing in the shadow of the golfing legend, Mitchell Berry nailed a hole-in-one on the first hole. DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Mitchell Berry, 15, left, can't believe hitting a hole in one on the first green. Joe Piggott, middle, and Amelia Garvey, right, congratulate him. 
"You couldn't have scripted a better start," club chairman Mike Cross said. 
READ MORE: 
Berry, Joe Piggott and Amelia Garvey were the lucky trio to walk the fairways with Sir Bob and while the 80-year-old may not have won the first hole, he won the round, hitting 73. DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
A large gallery followed as Sir Bob Charles around the Kaiapoi Gold Club. 
Berry, who has only been playing for 12 months, scored 74, as did Piggott, and Garvey had 75 playing off the white tees. 
"They did the club proud," Cross said. 
"They were a bit nervous for obvious reasons. They were playing with a legend and in front of a big crowd. DAVID WALKER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Amelia Garvey shares a laugh with Sir Bob Charles. 
"Joe said said to me 'it will probably be the biggest crowd I ever play in front of" but they all played well." 
Whether they make it it big or not, they will never forget their round with Sir Bob. 
And Sir Bob may never forget the time a 15-year-old showed him up off the first tee. 
The left-hander last played the Kaiapoi course 60 years ago when he was still an amateur, playing for Christchurch in the Woodward Cup. - Stuff
